issues.description: The problem statement explicitly requires initializing the animals ArrayList in a constructor with no arguments (a public no-arg constructor). The solution implementation of Farm only provides a constructor with an int parameter (public Farm(int initialCapacity)) and does not provide a no-argument constructor. This is a structural mismatch: students and the provided Main expect to be able to instantiate new Farm() (no-arg), and the problem text clearly instructs a no-arg constructor. The difference in constructor signatures may confuse students and cause tests or example code that call new Farm() to fail.
issues.suggested_fix: Provide a public no-argument constructor in Farm that initializes the animals list (e.g. public Farm() { this.animals = new ArrayList<>(); }). Alternatively, retain the int-parameter constructor but also add the required no-arg constructor so code and tests that call new Farm() per the problem statement and Main.java work as intended.
